title: International Scenes: Some Stories in Korea
short_summary: This article explores the cyber capabilities of North Korea, detailing its internet infrastructure, notable cyber attacks against South Korea, and the potential motivations behind these attacks. It provides a historical context of the Korean Peninsula's division and its implications on cyber warfare.
summary:
The article begins by outlining the historical and political context of the Korean Peninsula, emphasizing the ideological divide between North and South Korea. It discusses the limited internet access in North Korea, which has been largely restricted to an intranet system, and highlights the country's attempts to establish a presence online through various websites and email services. The piece also delves into North Korea's cyber capabilities, suggesting that the nation has developed a cadre of skilled hackers capable of executing sophisticated cyber operations, potentially rivaling those of other nations like the CIA.

The article further details two significant cyber attacks against South Korea: the 7.7 DDoS attack in 2009 and the 3.4 DDoS attack in 2011. It describes the methodologies employed in these attacks, including the use of botnets and various flooding techniques, and discusses the political motivations behind them. The piece concludes with reflections on the future of cyber warfare on the Korean Peninsula, suggesting that as tensions persist, so too will the likelihood of further cyber confrontations, necessitating ongoing vigilance and preparedness from South Korea.
